CPAC stands for Conservative Political Action Conference. It is an annual political conference attended by conservative activists and politicians from across the United States. The conference is hosted by the American Conservative Union (ACU) and has been held every year since 1974.

The purpose of CPAC is to provide a platform for conservative leaders, activists, and organizations to discuss and promote conservative values, policies, and ideas. The conference typically features keynote speeches, panel discussions, and networking opportunities for attendees.

CPAC has become a major event on the American political calendar, with prominent conservative figures and organizations participating each year. The conference has also been a launching pad for presidential campaigns, with many candidates using the event to build support and momentum.

The topics discussed at CPAC vary from year to year but generally focus on issues important to conservatives, such as limited government, free markets, traditional values, and national defense. The conference also serves as a venue for showcasing new ideas and emerging leaders in the conservative movement.

Overall, CPAC is an important event in the conservative political world and serves as a platform for promoting and advancing conservative ideas and policies.
what candidates for president have used CPAC as a launching pad?

Several candidates for president have used CPAC as a launching pad for their campaigns over the years. Some of the most notable examples include:

1. Ronald Reagan: Reagan delivered a speech at the very first CPAC in 1974 and went on to win the Republican nomination for president in 1980.
2. George W. Bush: Bush spoke at CPAC several times in the late 1990s and early 2000s, using the conference to build support for his presidential campaign in 2000.
3. Mitt Romney: Romney addressed CPAC in 2007, helping to build momentum for his ultimately unsuccessful 2008 presidential bid. He also spoke at the conference in 2012, when he went on to win the Republican nomination.
4. Ted Cruz: Cruz first gained national attention with a speech at CPAC in 2013, where he famously called for the repeal of Obamacare. He went on to run for president in 2016.
5. Donald Trump: Trump has been a frequent speaker at CPAC since the early 2010s, and he used the conference to build support for his successful presidential campaign in 2016.

These are just a few examples of presidential candidates who have used CPAC as a launching pad for their campaigns. The conference has become an important venue for conservatives to rally around potential presidential candidates and to build support for their campaigns.
